993938504580239361.text: It's so refreshing to hear these principles clearly articulated by a top regulator. The metaphor is beaches not sandboxes. Freedom with lifeguards for emergencies. Again, the whole speech is here and worth reading: https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/speech-peirce-050218 …

993938145942081539.text: "even if the agency side-steps this trap, it may fall into another. The regulator may insert itself inappropriately into the creative process.  The regulator should be careful not to try to control the development of new technologies."

993938065570910208.text: "undue focus on potential harm can result in an agency’s leading with its enforcement powers, & ultimately setting itself up as industry’s adversary.  While a regulator should not be too chummy w/ the industry it regulates, creating a hostile relationship carries its own risks"

993937674162630656.text: "Unlike many other innovations in the financial world, much of this development is being done—not by financial firms, which are steeped in our regulatory environment—but by firms in the technology space, which may be unfamiliar ... with the agency."

993937506063306757.text: "I recommend that the SEC set up a web page devoted to questions and comments about ICOs, tokens, distributed ledger, and other crypto concepts.[16]  We already have an email address—fintech@sec.gov...A website would be easier for innovators to find."

993937147894878208.text: "My fear that regulators will grab hold of the shovels and buckets is why I am often wary of so-called regulatory sandboxes."

993936519047077894.text: "The law deserves respect, but technological progress should not be bound by the limits of the regulator’s lawyerly imagination." 989207582974840832.text: Hardest thing to grok in securities law wrt cryptocurrencies/tokens: Even though a bitcoin or an ether is an intangible asset it's still bought and sold, owned, and understood as a physical tangible asset that can be EMPLOYED in an enterprise without BECOMING the enterprise.

989146280764026880.text: "a complete cure for hysteria" jesus I'm glad I don't live in the 19th century.https://twitter.com/doctorow/status/989145829196918784 …

989145453307551745.text: ...that can be EMPLOYED in an enterprise without BECOMING the enterprise.

989145348508733440.text: It's becoming clearer to me that the big thing you need to help a judge or a regulator understand is that even though a bitcoin or an ether is an intangible asset it's still bought and sold, owned, and understood as a physical tangible asset...

989144863747792897.text: The two only come together because the sale of the tangible asset is indicia of a promoter-investor relationship, which along with expectations and reliance on efforts gets you to an investment contract. BUT the tangible asset doesn't become a security! would be nonsense.

989144458468917248.text: In all of these cases there are  **two** distinct assets. The security (which is the relationship between the promoter and the investor) and the physical/tangible assets or interest in assets.

989143915537182726.text: Drew found an awesome quote. The Howey line of cases is always predicated on a sale of a "tangible interest" that has "intrinsic value independent of the... enterprise." 967078936189521921.text: 6/ and well-functioning open cryptocurrencies (e.g. bitcoin or ethereum) have a BIG leg up on tractors because they have hundreds of independent developers and there's no restrictive copyright/patent licensing that limits who is allowed to put forward ongoing development efforts.

967077913542750208.text: 5/ tokens can be like tractors -- they work/have some value even if the issuer disappears, albeit they don't work as well as if the issuer had stuck around; or they can be more like stock -- they are near worthless unless issuer keeps promises they made about future effort.

967076759547105280.text: 4/ Now. Of course they are not. Why? Because tractor still has some value independent of those efforts (unlike a share of stock that is mere paper without efforts of issuer).

967070491444948993.text: 3/ I can only conclude that John Deere tractors are securities.

967070397979119617.text: 2/ so when you buy a John Deere tractor you are (a) investing your money in a (b) common enterprise because you expect to own a profitable property. And you (c) rely on the continued efforts of John Deere to ensure that profitability.

967068714179940352.text: 1/ Today's John Deere tractors simply don't work and can't be fixed without access to proprietary software maintained by the company. Their value, including their resale value, is highly dependent on the continued efforts of the manufacturer to keep that software up to date.pic.twitter.com/Nnom0wcNFd

960574746797772805.text: 12/ All in all, very comprehensive, helpful, and encouraging portrait of the cryptocurrency regulatory space. Confident "we got this" from the Chairman.

960574478492360706.text: 11/ ON LEVERAGE: "I am particularly concerned about market participants who extend to customers credit in U.S. dollars – a relatively stable asset – to enable the purchase of cryptocurrencies, which, in recent experience, have proven to be a more volatile asset."

960574308262309889.text: 10/ ON REG D: "It is possible to conduct an offer and sales of securities, including an ICO, without triggering the SEC’s registration requirements. just as with a Regulation D exempt offering [for products], an ICO that is a security can be structured so that it qualifies."

960573917499985921.text: 9/ Coin Center has a brand new report on exactly how Congress and Federal regulators could go about rationalizing the state-by-state approach:https://coincenter.org/entry/money-transmission-licensing-is-broken-here-s-how-to-fix-it …

960573594978979840.text: 8/ ON STATES AND UNIFIED FEDERAL APPROACH: "we are open to exploring with Congress, as well as with our federal and state colleagues, whether increased federal regulation of cryptocurrency trading platforms is necessary or appropriate.

960573503136325632.text: 7/ ON STATES: "U.S.-based cryptocurrency trading platforms have elected to be regulated as money-transmission services. ... these predominantly state-regulated payment services have not been subject to direct oversight by the SEC or the CFTC."

960573289180618753.text: 6/ ...ambit of a securities offer and sale is a facts-and-circumstances analysis, utilizing a principles-based framework that has served American companies and American investors well through periods of innovation and change for over 80 years." e.g. old tools = best tools.

960573133978824705.text: 5/ ON HOWEY TEST & CLASSIFICATION OF CRYPTO: "there are cryptocurrencies that, at least as currently designed, promoted and used, do not appear to be securities" Very clear and significant; didn't say which but that'd be a lot to ask. Also: "determining what falls within the...

960573064412090369.text: 4/ ON INNOVATION: "These warnings are not an effort to undermine the fostering of innovation through our capital markets – America was built on the ingenuity, vision and spirit of entrepreneurs who tackled old and new problems in new, innovative ways."

960573010808852480.text: 3/ Additionally, interesting tidbits: (a) Reg D works for ICOs e.g. SAFT sales can fit (b) concern over leveraged trading (c) ETF will take time to sort out issues, not ready now.

960572946786988037.text: 2/ Clayton emphasizes (1) preserving innovation (2) continued efficacy of Howey test for judging whether crypto/token is a security (3) SEC & CFTC together have situation under control (4) states may not be the best choice for preeminent regulator of exchanges.

956175407086149632.text: And I've no intent to disparage or minimize the accomplishments of those in the Apollo program. It was an incredible achievement. The historical context, however, is all quite alarming as compared with today.

956174985013354496.text: Von Braun had a previous life building the first rocket weapons for the Nazis (to shoot at London). Musk made an Internet payments company and then produced the first successful line of electric cars (motivated in part by a desire to address global warming).

956173902513815552.text: Those who have lingering doubts about capitalism's ability to make the world more peaceful and more livable... Take note of the contrast.

956173611798179847.text: Also, which world would you want to live in? (A) behemoth governments are lobbing mountains of cash at programs that hurl handful of citizens at Earth's largest satellite? Or (B) random dude starts profitable company & tests amazing rocket by launching his car into space.
